questions.text: Which of the following are valid sources for CAPA initiation? (Select all that apply)

options.explanation: Customer complaints are a defined CAPA source.
Audit findings are a defined CAPA source.
Risk management findings are a defined CAPA source.
Performance reviews are not listed as a CAPA initiation source.

questions.text: What is the first step in the CAPA investigation process?

options.explanation: Root cause analysis is step 2; documenting the problem comes first.
Per the Investigation section, documenting the problem description is the first step.
Assigning owners happens during action planning, not investigation.
Corrective actions are defined during action planning, after investigation.

questions.text: What happens if a CAPA is verified as not effective?

options.explanation: Ineffective CAPAs must not be closed.
Per the Verification section, if not effective the CAPA must be escalated.
CAPA records must be maintained for audit purposes.
The SOP requires escalation, not waiting.

questions.text: Affected documents should be updated per SOP-001 (Document Control) during CAPA implementation.
questions.explanation: Per the Implementation section, affected documents are updated per SOP-001.

questions.text: Which root cause analysis techniques are mentioned in the CAPA procedure?

options.explanation: The Investigation section lists '5 Whys, fishbone, etc.' as root cause analysis techniques.
These are statistical tools not specifically mentioned in the SOP.
Monte Carlo simulation is not mentioned in the CAPA procedure.
DOE is not mentioned in the CAPA procedure.
